BALTIM3RE, MD., JANUARY 26, 1922

RABBI WISE
Whatever may have been the sentiments and opinions of the
students who heard Rabbi -Wise last Thursday, they could not fail
to have been impressed and interested. The privilege of hearing a
speaker of Rabbi Wise's ability is seldom given a student body, for
few such men are in the country.
Rabbi Wise well defended his reputation as one of the foremost
orators in America, holding the attention of his audience from first
to last. We believe that the speaker who can hold the interest of a
college audience is a genuine orator and we take this opportunity of
paying our respects to Rabbi Wise and our thanks to Dr. Latane for
procuring such an interesting and able man,

A WORTHY ALUMNUS?
The following letter has been received from an alumnus in reply
to the circulars recently sent out by the News-Letter:
"Dear Sir:
Referring to your circular,—the reason you have not
heard from me ;s that I have thrown your paper into the
waste basket unopened, consequently did not see any of the
notices you sent me.
I do not care for the paper.
Very truly yours,
When we adopted the policy of putting a number of alumni on
the mailing list this fall, we made no effort to force them to accept
the publication. We simply took this means of bringing it to their
attention with the hope that they would be sufficiently interested in
the rapid development of the University to subscribe.
We do not object to the writer not caring for the paper, but we
do object to his having thrown it "into the waste basket unopened."
We believe that such action on his part shows a deplorable lack of
interest in his Alma Mater, and for that reason we question his value
to the University as an Alumnus.
After all, is the man, who receives his education from the University at a fraction of its actual cost, who receives the privilege of
being its representative and yet who,in after years, does not even take
sufficient interest to open a copy of his college paper, worthy to be
on the Alumni roll of that institution?

"Dick" Wood announces that in
the future the trials conducted by
the Student Council, if any shall
he found necessary, will be given
detailed publication, omitting only
the names of the men accused of
misdemeanors. It is thought that
this will throw light on the actual
ses of such cases and also on
Dff
the procedure of Council, and help
to offset the air of mystery which
has seemed to envelop the actions
uf the Council in the past.
With regard to the Honor System, an intensive campaign of education is to be waged from now
up to examination time, with the
end in view of making the system
so plain that no misunderstandings
will be possible. At the coming assembly, which is to be dedicated in
its entirety to this work, Mr. Christy and other speakers will address
the student body, and it is more
than important that everyone be
present, since the honor of the University seems to be compromised in
the question of the success or failure of the Honor System (although
what grounds there are for the idea
that it has failed are beyond imagination). It is hoped, therefore,
that the assembly will be marked
by a full attendance to show, if
nething else, that the student body
is heartily in favor of the Honor
System.
Short talks in the various classes
explanatory of the system are to be
given also as parts of the campaign
to clarify once and for all this matter of the working of the Honor
System.

LACROSSE PRACTICE TEMPORARILY SUSPENDED

How can a boxing team thrive
without some adequate place in
which the "knights of the squared
circle" can pair off? At present
that is the big question which is
troubling "Bob" Marino, to whom
Hopkins is indebted for the recent revival of boxing.

As Hopkins has planned a very
extensive lacrosse schedule for this
year, the most important thing at
this time is for all members of the
team, as well as the candidates, to
keep their names off the black list.
In order that such may be the case,
practice has been suspended until
after the mid-year exams.
A meeting of. the team was held
on Monday, January 16, at which
time Coach Johnny Knipp emphatically urged the "snow shoers" to
come through the exams with flyii:g colors, and also heartened the
men by telling of the excellent prospects which Hopkins has for a banner season this year.

BALTIM3RE, MD., JANUARY 26, 1922

RABBI WISE
Whatever may have been the sentiments and opinions of the
students who heard Rabbi -Wise last Thursday, they could not fail
to have been impressed and interested. The privilege of hearing a
speaker of Rabbi Wise's ability is seldom given a student body, for
few such men are in the country.
Rabbi Wise well defended his reputation as one of the foremost
orators in America, holding the attention of his audience from first
to last. We believe that the speaker who can hold the interest of a
college audience is a genuine orator and we take this opportunity of
paying our respects to Rabbi Wise and our thanks to Dr. Latane for
procuring such an interesting and able man,

A WORTHY ALUMNUS?
The following letter has been received from an alumnus in reply
to the circulars recently sent out by the News-Letter:
"Dear Sir:
Referring to your circular,—the reason you have not
heard from me ;s that I have thrown your paper into the
waste basket unopened, consequently did not see any of the
notices you sent me.
I do not care for the paper.
Very truly yours,
When we adopted the policy of putting a number of alumni on
the mailing list this fall, we made no effort to force them to accept
the publication. We simply took this means of bringing it to their
attention with the hope that they would be sufficiently interested in
the rapid development of the University to subscribe.
We do not object to the writer not caring for the paper, but we
do object to his having thrown it "into the waste basket unopened."
We believe that such action on his part shows a deplorable lack of
interest in his Alma Mater, and for that reason we question his value
to the University as an Alumnus.
After all, is the man, who receives his education from the University at a fraction of its actual cost, who receives the privilege of
being its representative and yet who,in after years, does not even take
sufficient interest to open a copy of his college paper, worthy to be
on the Alumni roll of that institution?

"Dick" Wood announces that in
the future the trials conducted by
the Student Council, if any shall
he found necessary, will be given
detailed publication, omitting only
the names of the men accused of
misdemeanors. It is thought that
this will throw light on the actual
ses of such cases and also on
Dff
the procedure of Council, and help
to offset the air of mystery which
has seemed to envelop the actions
uf the Council in the past.
With regard to the Honor System, an intensive campaign of education is to be waged from now
up to examination time, with the
end in view of making the system
so plain that no misunderstandings
will be possible. At the coming assembly, which is to be dedicated in
its entirety to this work, Mr. Christy and other speakers will address
the student body, and it is more
than important that everyone be
present, since the honor of the University seems to be compromised in
the question of the success or failure of the Honor System (although
what grounds there are for the idea
that it has failed are beyond imagination). It is hoped, therefore,
that the assembly will be marked
by a full attendance to show, if
nething else, that the student body
is heartily in favor of the Honor
System.
Short talks in the various classes
explanatory of the system are to be
given also as parts of the campaign
to clarify once and for all this matter of the working of the Honor
System.
